isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - SINGLE REDUCTION, SINGLE DRIVE AXLES: EATON - ADJUST - RING GEAR TOOTH CONTACT

svcsubproc.title: Axle Models 15040-23085
svcsubproc.para: After differential bearing preload and gear backlash adjustment is complete, check gear tooth contact pattern and adjust if necessary ( Figure 36).

svcsubproc.title: Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (New Gearing)
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 37.

figure.caption: Figure 37. Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (New Gearing)

svcsubproc.para: Paint ring gear teeth with marking compound and roll gear to obtain a contact pattern as shown in the drawings. The length of pattern in an unloaded condition is approximately one half to two thirds of the ring gear tooth in most models and ratios.

svcsubproc.title: Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (Used Gearing)
svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 38.

figure.caption: Figure 38. Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (Used Gearing)

svcsubproc.para: Used gearing may not display the square, even contact pattern found in new gear sets. The gear may have a "pocket" at heel end of contact pattern. The more use a gear has had, the more the pocket becomes the dominant characteristic of the pattern.

Adjust used gear sets to display the same contact pattern observed before disassembly. A correct pattern is up slightly off the toe and centers evenly along the face width between the top land and root. Otherwise, the length and shape of the pattern are highly variable and are considered acceptable as long as there is some pattern on toe end of the tooth.

note.para: Tooth contact patterns are a function of the relative positions of ring gear and pinion. An improper pattern will require relocation of either or both. Always adjust pinion position first, then ring gear position. Recheck backlash when done.

Before adjusting ring gear position in the following procedures, loosen thrust screw locknut and back off thrust screw (if so equipped). This procedure is necessary to provide adequate clearance and allow ring gear movement.

svcsubproc.title: Adjust Pinion Position
svcsubproc.para: If the contact pattern shows incorrect tooth depth contact, change drive pinion position by altering the shim pack under the cage and cup assembly. Used gears should achieve proper contact with the same shims removed from the axle at disassembly.
If the pattern is too close to the root of the gear tooth, add pinion shims ( Figure 39).

figure.caption: Figure 39. Pattern Too Close to Tooth Root

svcsubproc.para: If pattern is too close to the top land of gear tooth, remove pinion shims ( Figure 40).

figure.caption: Figure 40. Pattern Too Close to Tooth Top Land

note.para: Check ring gear backlash after each shim change and adjust if necessary to maintain correct backlash. Always recheck tooth contact pattern after making shim pack changes.

svcsubproc.title: Adjust Backlash
svcsubproc.para: If contact pattern shows incorrect face width contact, change backlash and recheck contact pattern.

With pattern concentrated at the toe (too far down tooth) ( Figure 41), ADD BACKLASH by loosening the bearing adjuster on the teeth side of ring gear several notches. Loosen the opposite adjuster one notch.

figure.caption: Figure 41. Pattern Too Close to Toe End of Tooth

svcsubproc.para: Return to adjuster on teeth side of ring gear and tighten adjuster until it contacts the bearing cup. Continue tightening the same adjuster 2 or 3 notches. Recheck backlash.

If the pattern is concentrated at the heel (too far up the tooth) ( Figure 42), REMOVE BACKLASH by loosening the bearing adjuster on the teeth side of ring gear several notches. Tighten the opposite adjuster one notch.

figure.caption: Figure 42. Pattern Too Far Along Tooth Toward Tooth Heel End

svcsubproc.para: Return to adjuster on teeth side of ring gear and tighten adjuster until it contacts the bearing cup. Continue tightening the same adjuster 2 or 3 notches. Recheck backlash.

svcsubproc.title: Axle Models 23105, 26105, 30105
svcsubproc.para: After differential bearing preload and gear backlash adjustment is complete, check gear tooth contact pattern and adjust if necessary.

svcsubproc.title: Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (New Gearing)
svcsubproc.para: Paint the ring gear teeth with marking compound and roll the gear to obtain a contact pattern. The correct pattern is well centered on the ring gear tooth with lengthwise contact up off the toe. The length of the pattern in an unloaded condition is approximately one half to two thirds of the ring gear tooth in most models and ratios ( Figure 43).

figure.caption: Figure 43. Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (New Gearing)

svcsubproc.title: Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (Used Gearing)
svcsubproc.para: Used gearing may not display the square, even contact pattern found in new gear sets. The gear will normally have a "pocket" at end of contact pattern. The more use a gear has had, the more the pocket becomes the dominant characteristic of the pattern ( Figure 44).

figure.caption: Figure 44. Correct Tooth Contact Pattern (Used Gearing)

svcsubproc.para: Adjust used gear sets to display the same contact pattern observed before disassembly. A correct pattern is up slightly off the toe and centers evenly along the face width between the top land and root. Otherwise, the length and shape of the pattern are highly variable and are considered acceptable as long as they do not run off the tooth at any point.

note.para: Tooth contact patterns are a function of the relative positions of the ring gear and pinion. An improper pattern will require relocation of either or both. Always adjust pinion position first, if necessary, then ring gear position. Recheck backlash when done.

Before adjusting ring gear position in the following procedures, loosen thrust screw locknut and back off thrust screw. This procedure is necessary to provide adequate clearance and allow ring gear movement.

svcsubproc.title: Adjust Pinion Position
svcsubproc.para: If the contact pattern shows incorrect tooth depth contact, change drive pinion position by altering the shim pack under the cage and cup assembly. Used gears should achieve proper contact with the same shims removed from the axle at disassembly.
If the pattern is too close to the root of the gear tooth, add pinion shims ( Figure 45).

figure.caption: Figure 45. Pattern Too Close or Off Tooth Root

svcsubproc.para: If pattern is too close to the top land of gear tooth, remove pinion shims ( Figure 46).

figure.caption: Figure 46. Pattern Tool Close to Tooth Top Land

note.para: Check ring gear backlash after each shim change and adjust if necessary to maintain correct backlash. Always recheck tooth contact pattern after making shim pack changes.

svcsubproc.title: Adjust Backlash
svcsubproc.para: If the contact pattern shows incorrect face width contact, change backlash and recheck the contact pattern.

With the pattern concentrated at the toe (too far down the tooth), ADD BACKLASH by loosening the bearing adjuster on the teeth side of ring gear several notches. Loosen the opposite adjuster one notch ( Figure 47).

figure.caption: Figure 47. Pattern Too Close to Edge of Tooth Toe

svcsubproc.para: Return to adjuster on teeth side of ring gear and tighten adjuster until it contacts the bearing cup. Continue tightening the same adjuster 2 or 3 notches. Recheck backlash.

If the pattern is concentrated at the heel (too far up the tooth), REMOVE BACKLASH by loosening the bearing adjuster on the teeth side of ring gear several notches. Tighten the opposite adjuster one notch ( Figure 48).

figure.caption: Figure 48. Pattern Too Far Along Tooth Toward Tooth Heel

svcsubproc.para: Return to adjuster on teeth side of ring gear and tighten adjuster until it contacts the bearing cup. Continue tightening the same adjuster 2 or 3 notches. Recheck backlash.

When preload, backlash and tooth contact are correct, align differential bearing adjusters with cotter pin holes (or locks), then tighten differential bearing cap bolts. Refer to the TORQUE CHART
. Install cotter pins (or locks). On 23105-30105 axles, lockwire differential bearing cap bolts.

step1.para: Thread thrust screw into the carrier until firm contact with the backface of the ring gear is made.

Loosen the thrust screw 1/4 turn to obtain the correct adjustment of 0.020 inch (0.50 mm) clearance between gear face and screw. Tighten jam nut. Refer to the TORQUE CHART
.
Hold thrust screw stationary with a wrench while tightening nut ( Figure 49).
Recheck to assure minimum clearance during full rotation of ring gear.

note.para: Drive Axle with Wheel Differential Lock. After carrier is assembled and adjusted (without Differential Lock), install Differential Lock.
Before installing carrier assembly, inspect and thoroughly clean interior of axle housing.

Use silicone rubber gasket compound on axle housing mating surface as shown in Figure 50. For the correct gasket material, refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual. Gasket compound will set in 20 minutes. Install carrier before compound sets or reapply.

figure.caption: Figure 50. Use Silicone Rubber Gasket Compound on Axle Housing Mating Surface

step1.para:
Install differential carrier assembly in axle housing. Install bolts and lockwashers. Refer to the TORQUE CHART
.

note.para: Fasteners using self-locking thread "patches" may be reused if not damaged, but should be secured by a few drops of Loctite #277 on threaded surface of differential carrier. Reused fasteners should be wiped clean of excess oil, but do not require special cleaning.

important.para: Drive Axle with Differential Lock. When installing axle shafts, make sure the double-splined axle shaft is installed in the shift unit side of the differential carrier.

step1.para: Install axle shaft, silicone gasket compound, and stud nuts. Connect driveline.
Fill axle with correct lube. Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

note.para: When axle has been disassembled or housing, gears, axle shafts or wheel equipment replaced, check axle assembly for proper differential action before operating vehicle. Wheels must rotate freely and independently.
